awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Kinematics and Chemistry of M33 - Determining the Past, Present and Future of the M31/M33 System
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will use the Keck telescope to study individual stars in M33, a companion galaxy to the Andromeda galaxy (M31). Using spectroscopy, they will obtain information about the motion and star formation history of the disk and potential halo of M33. They will use this information to learn if its interactions with M31 have influenced its evolution. The science program is integrated with a high school research program that will introduce students to cutting-edge research on M33's formation history.

With a mass ten times lower than M31's and a star formation rate 10 times higher, M33 is the best local analog for high z galaxies. Spectroscopic observations of resolved stars in M31 will provide measurements of the line-of-sight stellar velocities and dispersion and quantitative comparisons of the dynamics of the stellar and gas disk components. It will also produce the first iron and alpha-element abundance distributions for stars in M33. Finally, it will definitively determine of M33 has a stellar halo. This chemo-dynamical analysis will provide critical observational constraints on internal and external heating mechanisms affecting low-mass stellar disks. It will also constrain models of M33's orbit around M31, yielding insights into whether M33 is on first infall or has interacted substantially with M31 in the past.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This report summarizes the key project outcomes that emerged in the course of this three-year National Science Foundation grant (program duration: 9/1/2019 to 8/31/2022). About six months after the start of this grant, the world was in the grip of the COVID-19 global pandemic. At the end of the grant, the pandemic was not over in any sense of the word. The research team did the best they could under these trying conditions.

 

Intellectual Merit——

The key science finding was the discovery of an inner stellar halo in the Triangulum galaxy (M33). The stellar halo of a galaxy is a structural subcomponent in which stars are distributed in a spherical or spheroidal configuration. Stars in the halo orbit around the center of the galaxy but the orbital planes are different from one star to the next. It has long been known that most (all?) of M33's stars reside in a disk and it has long been debated whether M33 has a stellar halo. This NSF funded program has clearly shown the presence of a stellar halo in the inner regions of the galaxy. In contrast to the disk which contains a mix of young, intermediate-age and old stars, the halo contains mostly old and perhaps some intermediate-age stars. The main implication of this study is that even low mass galaxies like M33 have significant structural and dynamical complexity, not unlike their more massive galactic counterparts.

A second key science finding was the discovery of "weak CN" stars in M33. Such stars were first found in the Andromeda galaxy (M31) in a previous NSF funded study. These stars are characterized by unusual spectra: weak CN spectral absorption features, stronger versions of which are characteristic of so-called "carbon stars", are superposed on an otherwise normal spectrum with oxygen rich spectral absorption features (e.g., TiO bands, Ca II infrared triplet). It is clear from the location of M33's weak CN stars in a color-magnitude diagram (Herzsprung-Russell diagram) that these stars are associated with the red helium burning phase of massive (5 to 10 solar mass) stars that have evolved off the main sequence.

 

Broader Impacts——

This NSF funded program has led to the expansion of the Science Internship Program (SIP – https://sip.ucsc.edu/) at the University of California Santa Cruz. Started in 2009, this summer program engages bright motivated high school students from all backgrounds in open ended research at the university level. There is a strong focus on students from historically excluded groups. The high school students are mentored by PhD students, postdocs, research staff, and faculty. During all three summers covered by the NSF grant period (2020, 2021, and 2022), the COVID-19 pandemic forced the SIP program to operate 100% online. This turned out to be a blessing in disguise: the online format opened up access to many more students than before, especially those with limited travel resources.

The pandemic induced shutdown also led to the development of an innovative outreach initiative called Shadow the Scientists (StS – https://shadow.ucsc.edu/). This initiative allows students, educators, and others from any location to eavesdrop via Zoom on live telescope observing sessions. The StS ground work that was carried out during the last two years of the three year NSF grant ultimately led to a successful three year ~$1M grant proposal to Heising-Simons Foundation.


Last Modified: 05/22/2023
Modified by: Puragra Guha Thakurta
